oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A tale of the Early Race about the !khau lizard, who brings home his own flesh as food so that his wife will think he has brought home a Quagga. Eventually the wife tells their child to go out with his father and see what flesh he is bringing and the child sees his father go into a whirlwind and come out rolling his flesh in a net. The woman throws away the husband's flesh and leaves him for her father's people. 1) See also Song of the !kau's child, 2) p.7113v: |han=kass'o heard this story from his mother (|xabbi-an), 3) p.7119opp: about an insect, 4) p.7119v: see Aquilae's water, 5) p.7139v: how people swallow raw liver, 6) See also The death of the !kau (a lizard of the genus Agama) and Song of the !kau's child, and Remarks by |han=kass'o on the preceding story (The death of the !kau), 7) This story is found in Books VIII-12 and Book VIII-13.
